title: 918 Itha
text:
918 Itha (<a href="Minor%20planet%20provisional%20designation">"prov. designation"</a>: "or" ) is a stony <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> and the namesake as well as the principal body of the <a href="Itha%20family">Itha family</a>, located in the outer region of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>. It was discovered by German astronomer <a href="Karl%20Reinmuth">Karl Reinmuth</a> at the <a href="Heidelberg%20Observatory">Heidelberg Observatory</a> on 22 August 1919. The <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-type asteroid</a> has a notably short <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of only 3.5 hours and measures approximately in diameter. It was named "Itha", a female name taken from the almanac "<a href="Lahrer%20Hinkender%20Bote">Lahrer Hinkender Bote</a>", unrelated to the discoverer's contemporaries.
Orbit and classification.
When applying the synthetic <a href="hierarchical%20clustering%20method">hierarchical clustering method</a> (HCM) by <a href="David%20Nesvorn%C3%BD">Nesvorný</a>, "Itha" is the principal body and namesake of the <a href="Itha%20family">Itha family</a> (), a small <a href="Asteroid%20family">family</a> of stony asteroids with only a few dozen known members. Other larger and low-numbered members of this family include <a href="968%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BPetunia">968 Petunia</a>, <a href="1067%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BLunaria">1067 Lunaria</a>, <a href="3787%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BAivazovskij">3787 Aivazovskij</a>, <a href="4119%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BMiles">4119 Miles</a> and <a href="5232%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BJordaens">5232 Jordaens</a>. However, according to another HCM-analysis by <a href="Andrea%20Milani%20%28mathematician%29">Milani</a> and <a href="Zoran%20Kne%C5%BEevi%C4%87%20%28astronomer%29">Knežević</a> (AstDys), "Itha" is a <a href="background%20asteroid">background asteroid</a> as it is not a legitimate family in their analysis. It orbits the Sun in the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">outer</a> asteroid belt at a distance of 2.3–3.4 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 4 years and 10 months (1,770 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 2.86 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.19 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 12<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. "Itha" was first observed as () at the U.S. Taunton Observatory in Massachusetts. The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins at <a href="Heidelberg%20Observatory">Heidelberg Observatory</a> on 23 August 1919, the night after its official discovery observation.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named "Itha", picked from the "<a href="Lahrer%20Hinkender%20Bote">Lahrer Hinkender Bote</a>", an <a href="almanac">almanac</a> which was published in <a href="Lahr">Lahr</a>, southern Germany. Especially in the <a href="Alemannic%20German">alemannic-speaking</a> region, a "Hinkender Bote" (lit. "limping messenger") was very popular from the late 17th throughout the early 20th century. The <a href="Calendar%20%28stationery%29">calendar</a> section contains <a href="feast%20days">feast days</a>, the dates of important fairs and <a href="Ephemeris">astronomical ephemerides</a>. For 15 January, the calendar gives "Itha" as the German <a href="name%20day">name day</a> analogue next to "Maurus" and "Habakuk", the protestant and catholic entries in the <a href="calendar%20of%20saints">calendar of saints</a>, likely referring to <a href="Saint%20Maurus">Saint Maurus</a> and prophet <a href="Habakkuk">Habakkuk</a>.
Reinmuth's "calendar names".
As with 22 other asteroids – starting with <a href="913%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BOtila">913 Otila</a>, and ending with <a href="1144%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BOda">1144 Oda</a> – Reinmuth selected names from this calendar due to his many asteroid discoveries that he had trouble thinking of proper names. These names are not related to the discoverer's contemporaries. <a href="Lutz%20Schmadel">Lutz Schmadel</a>, the author of the "Dictionary of Minor Planet Names" learned about Reinmuth's source of inspiration from private communications with Dutch astronomer <a href="Ingrid%20van%20Houten-Groeneveld">Ingrid van Houten-Groeneveld</a>, who worked as a young astronomer at Heidelberg.
Physical characteristics.
"Itha" is an <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-type asteroid</a> in the SMASS-I classification by Xu (1995). This agrees with the overall <a href="Asteroid%20spectral%20type">spectral type</a> for members of the Itha family. 
Rotation period.
In June 2011, a rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Itha" was obtained from <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations by <a href="Julian%20Oey">Julian Oey</a> at Kingsgrove Observatory , Australia, in collaboration with three Argentinian astronomers. Lightcurve analysis gave a well-defined <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of hours with a brightness variation of <a href="Magnitude%20%28astronomy%29">magnitude</a> (). Two modeled lightcurves using photometric data from the "Lowell Photometric Database" and from the BlueEye600 robotic telescope at <a href="Ond%C5%99ejov%20Observatory">Ondřejov Observatory</a> gave a sidereal period of and , respectively. The modelling of the former gave two <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">poles</a> at (59.0°, −59.0°) and (249.0°, −72.0°), while the one of the latter gave only one pole at (72.0°, −54.0°) in <a href="Ecliptic%20coordinate%20system">ecliptic coordinates</a> (λ, β).
Diameter and albedo.
According to the surveys carried out by the Infrared Astronomical Satellite <a href="IRAS">IRAS</a>, the Japanese <a href="Akari%20%28satellite%29">Akari satellite</a>, and the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a> (WISE), "Itha" measures (), () and () kilometers in diameter, and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of (), () and (), respectively. The "Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link" derives an albedo of 0.2412 and a diameter of 20.53 km based on an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 10.6. Other published mean-diameters by the WISE team include () and () with corresponding albedos of () and ().
